Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Diasporas' Participation in Social Change

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
During the 2011 and ongoing "Arab Spring" period, revolutions against dictatorships emerged in Libya, Yemen, and Syria. Anti-regime activism, however, was not constrained by state borders. Members of these countries' diasporas in the United States and Great Britain also mobilized to support the revolutions, but did so in very different ways over time. Scholars argue that transnational diaspora movements in Western, democratic states can and do shape homeland conflicts in significant ways. However, existing studies have not systematically analyzed how diasporas mobilize to assist their respective homelands during crisis periods. Nor have such studies compared diaspora movements' efforts over time, or explained variation in their collective action dynamics and roles in homeland conflicts. This research project, therefore, addresses the following questions: 1) how do diasporas mobilize to support revolutions in the homeland, and 2) why do their respective movements and potential for influence differ significantly, specifically in the scope, intensity, and duration of their collection actions?

This research will address these questions with an in-depth comparative case analysis of these countries' diasporas' anti-regime movements across the U.S. and Britain using more than two hundred original interviews with activists, as well as the public statements and calls to action produced by diaspora advocacy organizations. The data will be coded using qualitative analytical software in order to discern the scope, intensity, and duration of diaspora movements. Using the constant comparative method, this study will test theoretically-derived propositions explaining movement dynamics and refine these arguments based on the empirical analysis. Based on theories of social movement mobilization, it is proposed that four primary factors shape anti-regime movement trajectories: 1) the biographical and identity-based characteristics of the anti-regime activist community; 2) the pace and degree of violent repression in the homeland; 3) the relative opportunities and constraints posed by diasporas' domestic contexts; and 4) the types of resources channeled into the anti-regime effort. The findings will be used to extend and refine theories of transnational social movements, diaspora mobilization, and social change.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In 2011, the world watched in disbelief as a tidal wave of protests swept across the Middle East, producing a cascade of revolutions known as the Arab Spring. While these uprisings marked an explosive turn against longstanding dictatorships in the region, this dissertation project finds that the revolutions also galvanized transnational movements against authoritarian regimes by Middle Easterners the world over. In other to understand the unprecedented mobilization of Arab diasporas for democracy during this period, this research compares how Syrians, Libyans, and Yemenis mobilized to support the 2011 revolutions from the U.S. and Great Britain, and asks why their roles the uprisings varied significantly. For example, while Yemenis held demonstrations abroad for a short time, Libyans mobilized from overseas to assist rebels on the ground for the duration of the rebellion. Between 2011 and 2014, the Syrians, meanwhile, have largely shifted their activism from holding protests to providing humanitarian relief to needy civilians directly. Existing theories suggest that diasporas in liberal Western countries are ideally positioned to meddle in home-country politics and assist repressed populations overseas. And yet, such theories cannot explain why all three diasporas were relatively un-mobilized before the revolutions, or why the character of their collective action dynamics varied significantly during the Arab Spring.

The Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Grant enabled the co-Primary Investigator to complete the data collection necessary for this comparative case study. This involved conducting 70 interviews with Syrian activists in 2014, including in-person interviews with activists in diaspora hub communities such as London, Manchester, Bristol, and across southern California, interviews via Skype with activists located in the midwestern and eastern United States, and the transcription of the raw recordings into codable text. In all, the dissertation is based on data that include a total of 248 original in-depth interviews with activists in the Syrian, Libyan, and Yemeni diasporas. These data reveal the duration, strength, intensity, and organizational characteristics of anti-regime activism abroad that would be unknowable through other methods. These data were analyzed using process-tracing methods and coding procedures in NVivo, a qualitative analytical software, to understand how the diasporas mobilized during the 2011 revolutions and why their roles in the revolutions varied. 

The analysis demonstrates that diaspora mobilization dynamics are shaped by four factors. First, the study shows that their transnational mobilization was largely inhibited before 2011 because the home-country regimes sanctioned dissidents overseas. Second, the dissertation describes how escalations in violence during the Arab Spring disrupted the effects of this repression in ways that produced public anti-regime activism in the U.S. and Britain. Third, the analysis describes how the unfolding conflicts created or blocked pathways for activists to assist their allies on the ground over time. Lastly, the author argues that the responses of third parties to the revolutions, including their host-country governments, channeled diaspora mobilization in specific ways. The study concludes that the revolutions liberated the diasporas to revolt against dictatorships at home, but that diaspora movements only play a role in anti-authoritarian rebellions when conflicts 1) escalate into zero-sum crises against home-country regimes, and 2) create pathways for activists abroad to transfer capital, such as labor and expertise, to their compatriots on the ground.
